name: Celtic Mythology
tagline: The Druids, Tuatha D√© Danann, and Otherworld
description: Explore Celtic myths of the Tuatha D√© Danann, druidic wisdom, sacred groves, and the mysterious Otherworld.
overview: Celtic mythology encompasses the religious beliefs and narratives of the Celtic peoples across Ireland, Scotland, Wales, and Gaul (France). The Irish tradition features the Tuatha D√© Danann (People of the Goddess Danu) - divine beings who conquered Ireland before retreating into the sidhe (fairy mounds). Welsh mythology includes the Mabinogi tales and Arthurian legends. Celtic mythology emphasizes: the Otherworld accessible through mounds and water, druidic wisdom and magic, sacred trees and groves, seasonal festivals (Samhain, Beltane, Imbolc, Lughnasadh), warrior culture and cattle raids, shape-shifting, prophecy, and the interplay between mortal and divine realms. Unlike systematized mythologies, Celtic tradition survived fragmentarily through medieval Christian scribes.

culturalContext.primarySources: Ulster Cycle, Mythological Cycle, Mabinogion, medieval Irish texts

sections.title: Tuatha D√© Danann
sections.body:
The divine race who conquered Ireland, bringing four magical treasures:

**Dagda:** Father-god, owns magic cauldron of plenty and club that kills and resurrects.
**Lugh:** Master of all arts, sun god, warrior. Led Tuatha D√© to victory.
**Brigid:** Goddess of poetry, healing, smithcraft. Later Christianized as St. Brigid.
**Morrigan:** Phantom queen, war goddess, shape-shifter (crow/raven).
**Nuada:** First king, lost arm in battle, received silver prosthetic.
**Danu:** Mother goddess, ancestress of the Tuatha D√©.

Defeated by the Milesians (mortal Irish), they retreated into sidhe mounds, becoming the fairy folk (aos s√≠).
